images.caption: A snow monkey sat on a tree with Kyoto in the background.
images.alt: A snow monkey sat on a tree with the city of Kyoto in the background.

images.caption: Snow monkeys looking affectionate at Monkey Park Iwatayama.
images.alt: Snow monkeys sat atop a hill with the city of Kyoto in the background.

images.caption: A buddhist shrine near Arashiyama Park.
images.alt: Buddhist shrine surrounded by a well-manicured garden.

images.caption: Sunset view from the top Yotsu-suji hill.
images.alt: Sunset view over the city of Kyoto.

images.caption: Senbon Torii(thousands of torii gates) of Fushimi-Inari shrine.
images.alt: The famous red Shinto shrine gates of Fushimi-Inari.

images.caption: The main shrine of Fushimi-Inari.
images.alt: View of the main shrine.

images.caption: Statue of the Fushimi fox on the walk up Yotsu-suji hill.
images.alt: Fox statue on the side of the stairs leading up the hill.

images.caption: The entrance leading to Fushimi-Inari shrine. There were numerous vendors selling different kinds of delicious street food.
images.alt: Street leading to Fushimi-Inari, full of people moving to and from the shrine as well as street food vendors on the side.

images.caption: A delicious bowl of ramen with a pint of beer.
images.alt: Bowl of tonkotsu ramen.

images.caption: Probably the most comfortable train journey of my life.
images.alt: A bullet train looking sexy as it pulls into the station.

images.caption: Lake at Shinjuku Gyoen park.
images.alt: View of the lake at Shinjuku Gyoen park.
Shrine sat amidst the trees at Shinjuku Gyoen.

images.caption: Kazaridaru(sake barrels) near Meiji Jingu shrine.
images.alt: Sake barrels used as decoration near the Meiji Jingu shrine.

images.caption: Chozuya(cleansing basin) at the entrance of Meiji Jingu. Before entering shrines or temples, it is customary to cleanse oneself by using the Chosuya.
images.alt: Water basin used for the tradition of purifying yourself prior to entering temples or shrines.

images.caption: Meiji Jingu temple.
images.alt: View of the Meiji Jingu temple courtyard.

images.caption: Ginza Street in Tokyo.
images.alt: High-end shopping street in the heart of Tokyo.

images.caption: The Bally store at Ginza
images.alt: Bally store at Ginza street.

images.caption: The famous Shibuya scramble crossing.
images.alt: Street crossing at Shibuya, famous due to being featured in many movies set in Tokyo.

images.caption: Exploring the streets of Shibuya.

images.alt: Skyline panorama of Tokyo.
View of the skyscrapers.

images.caption: Gyoza
images.alt: Dumplings, filled with ground meat and vegetables.

images.caption: Ramen
images.alt: Pork ramen soup, served with a soft-boiled egg.

images.caption: Loved the sushi restaurants.
images.alt: A conveyor belt serving sushi to customers while the chefs prepare more in the background.

images.caption: Sunset view over the marina.
images.alt: View over the marina at sunset showing the mountains in the distance.

images.caption: Walk down to the Playa Blanca beach.
images.alt: Stairs leading to the beach below.

images.caption: Volcanic vinviyard. Grape-growers dig holes and build stone walls to protect their vines from the strong winds.
images.alt: Holes in the ground used to protect grapes from the strong winds.

images.caption: Wine bottling machine.
images.alt: Machine used for bottling and labeling wine bottles.
Panoramic view over the volcanic landscape of the island.

images.caption: One of the more remote beaches on the island.
images.alt: View of a remote beach, taken from the water.

images.caption: Bun Cha(noodles with grilled pork). This is what £1 gets you on the streets of Hanoi.
images.alt: A bowl of broth served with a heaping portion of noodles.

images.caption: The Ho Chi Minh mausoleum in central Hanoi.
images.alt: The masoleum building where Ho Chi Minh lays.

images.caption: A heaping market full of vendors mostly selling clothes.
images.alt: A market building full of sellers mostly selling clothes.
A view of a rice field and the mountains in the distance.

images.caption: View from the hostel I was staying at. The highest peak in Indochina called Phan Xi Păng is somewhere in the clouds.
images.alt: Mountain view as seen from the my hostel.
View of the rice fields and mountains in the distance.

images.caption: Riding around on a scooter. Don't be like me and wear flip flops.
images.alt: Me being silly.
Sunset view from one of the hills near town.

images.caption: In the national park in the centre of the island.
images.alt: A look over the tree canopies in the rainforest.

images.caption: There are quite a few little villages that are floating on the water near Cat Ba.
images.alt: A fishing village on the water.

images.caption: Kayaking around the limestane islands.
images.alt: Vista of the scenery amidst the floating limestone islands.

images.caption: More views from the kayak.
images.alt: A view from the kayak

images.caption: The Bai Dinh pagoda.
images.alt: The rather tall Bai Dinh pagoda.

images.caption: View over Tam Coc.
images.alt: View from the top of the pagoda.

images.caption: Golden Buddha at the top floor of the pagoda.
images.alt: Glistening golden Buddha statue in the middle of a room located at the top of the pagoda.

images.caption: Boat tour around Trang An.
images.alt: A river surrounded by limestone mountains.

images.caption: The boat actually went through that cave. Had a near miss with the rocks.
images.alt: A cave goes through the middle of one of the limestone mountains.

images.caption: Cycling around the rice fields.
images.alt: The rice fields near Tam Coc provided a lovely scenery for a bike ride.

images.caption: Goofing around at the abandoned waterpark.
images.alt: Slides at the abandoned waterpark near Hue town.

images.caption: Ho Thuy Tien opened in 2004 and cost about three million US dollars to build. It closed not too long afterwards and everything that had been built on the site had just been left as it was. Abandoned.
images.alt: A big dragon attraction stands in the middle of a lake.

images.caption: Entrance to Hue imperial city.
images.alt: Gate leading into the imperial city of Hue.

images.caption: Pagoda near the imperial city.
images.alt: A temple found near the imperial city.

images.caption: Took a road trip between Hue and my next destination Hoi An. The Hai Van pass was popularised on Top Gear.
images.alt: Scooter with the sea in the background.

images.caption: Da Nang city in the distance. Ended up sleeping there and taking an extra half a day to complete the road trip.
images.alt: View of Da Nang city, the mid point between Hue and Hoi An.

images.caption: Abandoned resort, near the start of the Hai Van pass.
images.alt: Abandoned buildings part of a resort stood near the sea.
The long, windy road of the Hai Van Pass.

images.caption: Went on a cooking course. Soup is pho bo, middle plate is a banana blossom salad with chicken and fresh spring rolls. The last plate is Ca Tim Tron which is a type of stir fry with lemongrass, marinated eggplant, peanuts and shallots served over noodles.
images.alt: Cooking class creations, featuring pho bo, banana blossom salad, spring rolls and stir fry.

images.caption: I also felt like a ruin, after a night of drinking.. Don't mix 35 degree temperatures and hangovers.
images.alt: Ruins near Hoi An city.

images.caption: Rooftop bar view.
images.alt: View from a rooftop bar.

images.caption: Traffic in the city was pretty intense.
images.alt: Bustling traffic with everyone going about their business on scooters.

images.caption: Adapt. Overcome. Survive. Exploring the Cu Chi tunnels.
images.alt: Me goofing around.

images.caption: These tunnels were used as hiding spots by the Viet Cong during their fight with the American forces. The tunnels form a massive, multi-level network where the deeper you go, the smaller the tunnels get.
images.alt: Tunnel leading into the vast network underneath the soil.
